commentBody:
Certainly a ‚Äúlight and breezy‚Äù Friday for me. 
I thoroughly enjoyed it!
My wife sometimes orders an ESPRESSO MARTINI after dinner. Going forward, I will never not regale her with this clue when she does so. Sorry, Hon.

Easy breezy. 10 minutes. The Northwest was the last to fall. I was shocked, though, to be stumped about tennis clue. Never heard of HANA Madvlikova, probably because she won her last Major before I was born. I'd be glad to RANT about current Wimbledon Finalist Barbora Krejcikova, though, for anyone who cares...

I usually find Fridays harder than Saturdays. This was hard enough but a lot of fun. Loved the clue for ISNT and enjoyed seeing ESPRESSOMARTINI and AMERICANOS in the grid. I might know too much about Japanese animation, as I was racking my brain for obscure characters and didn‚Äôt see HELLOKITTY until it was almost filled in. I know of exactly one collaboration between Ja Rule and ASHANTI, and it‚Äôs a 2001 earworm that my siblings and I have great fondness for, so seeing them in today‚Äôs puzzle was a treat.

Not a very hard puzzle for me, for a Friday; less than a minute longer than the Thursday puzzle.  I did have a brain fart in one place, though.  For 17A, I was pretty sure that it had to be CRAZY STRAW, but the cross (ROTS) didn't compute for me.  So I just left that square blank and moved on.

I came back to that last square after I filled everything else it, and I said to myself, [Turns], ROTS, must be a shortening of "rotates"...totally forgetting that ROTS is a regular word that means "turns", like that produce sitting in my produce bin after we've eaten out a few too many times in a row. I guess the twists and turns of the CRAZY STRAW clue just had me stuck on physical turning in circles.

All on me.  Ninety-nine out of 100, nay, 999 out  of 1000 times, I would not have hiccupped on that cross.  I was actually surprised I had guessed right.

Must be tired tonight.
Will definitely never complain when a puzzle helps yield a PR for me. Cheers!

Not my fastest Friday ever, but definitely the earliest I‚Äôve ever completed one.

If not for FinK instead of YANK, I might have had a personal best.

I enjoyed this puzzle very much.  Thanks Malaika Handa. Well done.
750 puzzles solved and a Friday personal best. Thanks for this Malaika! Was a delight.

‚ÄúWhat connects money to everything‚Äù:
I had the I, and even though I knew it was wrong, I wanted IPAD there.

You know, the IPAD that is used to ask a tip from you whenever you get an ESPRESSO MARTINI, a SHORTBREAD, some DIGITAL ART, a HELLO KITTY tchotchke, or, basically, everything.

(Correct answer was better, though!)
Yay! My fasted Friday ever! Less than 9 minutes!

I enjoyed the puzzle. Even though I dislike coffee, ESPRESSOMARTINI was great as clued. Unlike others, I found this to be a steady solve. I finished under my average, but far away from my personal best for a Friday

Had an awful time in the NW, finding only SPCA, but the NE caved for me and I was able to work my way down the whole Eastern seaboard, then the South. Kept on going clockwise and took 4 minutes off my avg. 
Terrific cluing and everything solvable with crosses. 
Good puzzle.

Maybe this was just an easier than usual one, but I outdid my previous Friday record by quite a bit and with fewer hints too!
I enjoyed the multiple coffee and compost references, it felt tied together.

Wonderful puzzle! Thank you for a delightful outing!

I must agree with the constructor here in preferring human-created digital art to the works that AI "creates." I'm surprised that the editors would come up with such a clue. The creators of AI models like DALL-E have stolen so many human artists' creations off the internet - without their consent - in order to make DALL-E work, that I hesitate to give DALL-E's generated images the name "art"...

Anyhow, off my soapbox now. Loved this puzzle, definitely breezy for a Thursday night / Friday. Just what I needed!

Fast and sweet, which surprised me for a Friday, when I'm prone to break a sweat.

Because I start end-of-week puzzles at the bottom (it's the same strangeness that makes me read magazines from back to front,) at one point I had the whole Eastern half filled, while the West lay completely blank.

I had been feeling so proud thus far, I thought Karma was surely coming for me with the rest of the grid.
But some chipping away did the trick and I get to remain unusually smug and proud ‚Äì which means Karma will probably put me in my place tomorrow...

For now, I'll keep my smile and send out a great big thank you to Ms. Handa!

Remember back in March when there was a steady stream of complaints about how the puzzles got so much harder after Will had to step away? I'm starting to feel like thing have swung too far back in the other direction, with puzzles being significantly easier on average during the past couple months.  Maybe it's my imagination (my times would indicate otherwise), maybe it's just coincidence, or perhaps it's in response to the criticism that was leveled at the editors during that time.

Regardless, I enjoy bagging a good time on the easier Friday and Saturday puzzles as much as anyone, but I also enjoy the sense of accomplishment that comes with completing more challenging puzzles from time to time and wish a few more real workouts would be sprinkled in.

Well, my current streak of 1,827 days works out to exactly five years (even taking into account two leap days). It would have been even longer had I not forgotten to log on to the internet one day while on a European vacation in 2019. 

As for the puzzle it was a smooth solve tonight although I had to run the alphabet for _ANK at 43A. Sadly I decided to end the run at W which kind of worked for the clue.

I NEED to say that this felt like it had a travelling theme.  STOWing my luggage, with a pocketful of EUROS, ordering SHORT BREAD with AMERICANOS. HANDPICKing a SPA, and walking with a STRIPEd bag, just to take a selfie with HELLO KITTY. 

Very fun.

One of those puzzles where I HOP from top to side to bottom to middle, no need for pauses, but the POSTMALONE/ALT cross shot me down and I NEEDed to REZIP through the puzzle again for just one small hint to DIAL it in.  Lively and clever, especially that we got to HANDPICK ETSY in the puzzle over [Amazon's Handmade] in the clues. Forget the DIGITAL ART, and of course there was DALAI in the puzzle  (no [DALL-E] there).

Enjoy your ESPRESSO MARTINI, Malaika.  You gave us a winner of a puzzle.  Thank you!
No look ups on a Friday! I think that's a first for me!!
This started really slow for me, groping for a foothold after the first pass through the clues but then something clicked and I finished in under half my average Friday time.  A fun romp!

Someone here really likes her caffeine, starting the day with tea and shortbread, having an espresso martini in the middle of the puzzle (why wait?), and ending with an Americano (why sleep?)!

Then it's off to work, and thank God you've had your coffee because the boss is no-nonsense: "Try to keep up!" and (to the new kid, Leonardo, they just hired as an apprentice) "Stay in line!" -- Leonardo's been put on the task everyone calls the "paper route" -- hand-coloring Hello Kitty cels for the next anime Hello Kitty cartoon because when DALL-E does it, it just looks soulless. 

Once I asked Leonardo what he was drawing in his notebook. "It sorta looks like a helicopter," I said, peering over his shoulder. "Huh? It's a crazy straw," he said, "I just invented it." 

"And what are those lines?" 

"I call those 'stripes,'" Leonardo said, "Just made that up." 

"What are all those stripes, so close together?"

"That's a harp! Haven't you ever seen a harp before? They've been around, like, forever," Leonard said. 

"You're such a lyre," I told him.

Leonardo frowned. "Try to keep up," I said.
I had carp at 2D, which really made the NW difficult.

Any puzzle with SHORTBREAD is okay by me. Any tea left in that caddy from the other day?
 
Very breezy.  Barely needs an easy mode version.  Got tripped up briefly by thinking [Predator on a continental shelf] was a SUB.  Watched The Hunt for Red October one too many times, I guess.

I have... thoughts on this one.

1. Enjoyable, smooth, and often quite clever.  The euros clue was the best version I've seen and menus was good; money too.

2.  Honestly it seemed far too easy for a Friday; I really breezed through it quite quickly.

3.  I considered taking issue with the DALL-E clue, since some would claim it doesn't produce art, but then I stared agape at Americanos.  While quite easy, it just seems wrong.  Drip is one way to brew coffee.  Espresso is another.  An Americano certainly is not a way to brew coffee.  The brew is achieved from making espresso.  The Americano is basically a mixed drink.  Has anyone ever ordered "one drip coffee please"?

4.  The clue for staying in line seemed oddly specific / descriptive for such a simple bog standard answer, unless I'm missing something more clever.

5.  A Crazy Straw doesn't have all that many twists to be fair.  :) Although I just checked the original 1935 patent by the great Arthur P. Gildersleeve and it shows one loop through 4 loop versions.

Pre-boomer emus listened to The Great Gildersleeve on the radio.
Cheers Malaika! üç∏ Enjoy your espresso martini! What a fun puzzle! I wouldn't call it easy (I got stuck in NW at the end for a while) but it definitely sparkled! ‚ú®
Could someone explain 37 down, please? I got it with the crosses  but don‚Äôt ‚Äúget‚Äù it.  Thanks!

I was really surprised when "Drip alternatives" filled in from the crossings, but my guess that it must have to do with coffee was confirmed through googling. I still have a lot to learn but at 89 already I won't have enough time.

Then I found out that "drip" no longer comes close to meaning what I thought it did, "a dull or unattractive person." Yes, way too much to learn.
Too easy; not challenging enough for Friday.
i got so far on my own today! got espresso martini early and 3/4 of the grid fell into place after that. then came here for the rest haha. satisfying
This was a really great themeless! Very breezy indeed. I'll definitely search up some more of Malaika's puzzles in the archive, since this one was such a delight.
It is a sign of the times when 12D appears in a crossword. It's official. We live in a voter suppressed culture.

This is the first Friday ever where I completed about 3/4 of the puzzle without any lookups.  Usually I only get about 10 words before giving up.  Sometimes fewer.  Therefore, it seems mean to quibble, but could someone explain how a paper route is an assignment in a typical first job and not the job itself?  This was a major stumbling block for me.

Fresh and fun.

My daughter is home for the last summer before she graduates from college, and invited an early childhood friend with some mild learning disabilities (can‚Äôt read, but is a terrific server at a neighborhood bistro) to our mountain cabin for a long weekend of hiking, kayaking, playing cornhole, and grilling fish and vegetables.

Summer!

Well, HELLO KITTY, yes I will join you for tea and SHORTBREAD, but only if it‚Äôs my MIL‚Äôs recipe. She made the uber treat. 
Sadly, there‚Äôs no such thing as a decaf ESPRESSO MARTINI. I haven‚Äôt touched caffeine for over 30 years, or I‚Äôd join you in a heartbeat.
An interesting Friday offering. Yes, a little on the easier side but it doesn‚Äôt have to be a brain melt every Friday.
My first Friday I completed with no help!! Yay!!

Lots of interesting long entries, but as so often I certainly didn‚Äôt find it too easy for a Friday. 
 I can‚Äôt remember the last time I used a straw, CRAZY or not for a drink. ( and CRAZYSTRAW was one of the many things I didn‚Äôt knew today.  ( As always not a complaint) .
7D: I don‚Äôt get how ROTS are ‚ÄúTurns, perhaps‚Äù unless it‚Äôs an abbreviation for rotations, in which case the clue should have indicated it‚Äôs an abbreviation.

Not at all easy for me (hi suejean), but managed to work it all out. Way off-topic puzzle find today, but at least mildly interesting. A Sunday from July 2, 1995 with three 21 letter answers. Quite surprised that one of them appeared for the first and last time and the other two only ever appeared one other time. Anyway... BORNONTHEFOURTHOFJULY THESTARSPANGLEDBANNER IAMTHEYANKEEDOODLEBOY And some other cross referenced answers: FROMSEATO SHININGSEA PLEDGE ALLEGIANCE TOTHEFLAG Here's the Xword Info link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=7/2/1995&g=64&d=A I'll shut up now. ..

Here's my take today for an ongoing commentary on "how do you start to solve".

I'm interested to know how folks here employ different strategies.  How many start in the NW corner?

For me, I often scan for a short entry mid-puzzle that I'm 100% sure of, and then work off that word in all directions. 

One of my early entries today was HUIT -- I love the assurance of a factual answer. Then after warming up with a few like that, I'm ready for the puns and tricks. 

Where did you start today?

Gimme a minute.

I‚Äôm not going to read the column.
Not reading other comments.
(fingers in ears, ‚Äúlalalalala‚Äù‚Äù)

Just going to soak in my luxurious solve‚Ä¶

Aaaahhhhh‚Ä¶(How many As, how many Hs? Nobody knows.)

Egyptian pharaohs? 
(‚Ä¶please let it be RAMSES‚Ä¶please let it be RAMSES‚Ä¶)
Jewish noodles? (‚Ä¶please let it be KUGEL‚Ä¶)

And so on. 
Wildly satisfying. 
I cannot see a single weak link in this beaut.

And woke up to picture of the beautiful baby Essie.
Gave her momma a tough time, but c-section saved the day and all are exhausted, beautiful, and healthy.

It‚Äôs a beautiful Friday.


Now, I‚Äôll finish my puzzles and read that this was the ‚Äúeasiest ever‚Äù and ‚Äúdo better‚Ä¶‚Äù

Yada-yada-yada‚Ä¶

Malaika, superb. Thank you.

I hope you all have a surprisingly lovely weekend
that surpasses all expectations, no matter how high.

A gold star for my birthday. Woo Hoo!

Had to use the crosses to get the Rapper name and had drawl for TWANG but what to I, a transplanted Southerner know.

Thank you Makaika A  smooth solve.And, ko liked it too.

Well, this was a recipe, a perfect storm, actually, for a slam-bang solving experience.

I know from Malaika‚Äôs puzzles that her frame of reference diverges greatly, that her world is light years away, from mine.   It‚Äôs also become clear to me that she‚Äôs a skilled puzzlemaker.

The upshot is that her puzzles often have answers I don‚Äôt know, but her skill is such that I‚Äôve got a good chance of getting them, resulting in great pleasure for my brain.  

Why?  When one doesn‚Äôt know an answer, especially if it‚Äôs a word one has never come across, it requires the brain to make educated guesses from whatever letters that have been filled in from crosses.  ‚ÄúDoes this answer seem possible?  Could it fit the clue?  Will it work with surrounding words?‚Äù

Thus, the brain becomes super involved, and I don‚Äôt know about you, but my brain adores this.  Savors this.

Today‚Äôs puzzle brought several such answers ‚Äì all long ‚Äì transporting my brain to nirvana.  These moments of sweet labor were complemented by some glorious swaths of splat-fill.

Along the way were some beautiful answers ‚Äì HAND PICK, KUGEL, NO NONSENSE. There was also an impressive original clue for EEL, a word clued hundreds of times in the major outlets, but never with a ‚Äúcontinental shelf‚Äù angle. 

Very happy brain, with loveliness on the side ‚Äì yes, a slam-bang experience.  Thank you greatly for making this, Malaika!

Is this puzzle one that seems to solve itself, despite the protestations of my brain that I don‚Äôt have a clue?

Tis!


.
.

Very nice!

I usually don't comment here, but I have to say how much I love Malaika's crosswords! She's my favorite constructor. As a non-American, a lot of clues reference things that I've never heard of, or require knowledge of things like baseball players or local politicians. However, I always seem to get Malaika's clues, and am tickled when they reference Desi culture (none of those today though)!

Thank you for a great puzzle Malaika!
incredibly on the same wave length as miss malaika because how did i finish a Friday with no look-ups in under 15 minutes...
Quick, but not disappointingly so. Satisfying puzzle, thanks!

No one wants to see a caffeinated Nancy J.  I think I got a little buzz just from solving this puzzle.

Makaika's puzzles always seem so fresh.  This was a breezy romp that was over a little too fast.

Solved this one unaided, which I find hard to believe. Spent much of the time cursing the constructor for being on a different wavelength (planet?) from me, and for including too many proper nouns! But, in the end, even the many entries I didn't know ended up correctly filled in.

A challenging Friday puzzle/trivia contest. The cluing struck me as a bit uneven, with absolute gimmes like "Advice for voters waiting at crowded polling sites" and complete obscurities like "Let me tell you ..."

Well, I was certainly puzzled this morning, so kudos to the constructor and editors.
Like the puzzle. But soil is NOT a product of composting. So many better/more accurate clues for soil.
I was very proud of my answer for 42A: "SEEN IT" ‚Äì until I wasn't.

Girl, what a sparkly and entertaining puzzle that was!

I'm especially impressed to see the symmetrically-placed  Ramses the First and Ashant the First.

And both of them crossing the infamous Empress O'Martin the first!
Good morning. Close to a Friday PB. Yes, echoing others, it was great fun, and over too soon! Thanks Malaika!
Excellent Friday puzzle! Well done!!

A touch longer than

a Robyn Weintraub Friday,

but equally fun

That was terrific! I had a few bad guesses in the NW corner that made it the last to fall, and I had trouble getting a toehold all over the puzzle but there was *just* enough to get going, which is exactly what you want from a crossword puzzle. Well done!
There apparently isn‚Äôt a rapper called Postman One.
62 Across should be PLAGIARISM.

There were a lot of answers in this puzzle I didn't know -- probably because they were aimed at a demographic not my own.  POST MALONE; OPAL; ASHANTI; KAT; CRAZY STRAWS.  And AMERICANOS, as clued.  I thought that drip was a method of making coffee and AMERICANOS are a kind of coffee.  But then I don't know my AMERICANOS from my ESPRESSO MARTINIS.

Question of the day:  How can you make an ESPRESSO MARTINI with those non-coffee ingredients?  When I go back to read the comments, I'm sure some one will explain it.

But, wow, Malaika, your cluing is great!  It's tricky, it's always completely fair, and it does the thing I most want clues to do -- which is to provoke curiosity.  Loved the clues for ISN'T (11A); EUROS (8D); STRIPE (42A); MENUS (45A); DIAL (38D).  You've taken simple, ordinary words and made them special.

My subway had a gAP at first.  You're always being warned to WATCH THE GAP, so I'm always watching the gap -- which keeps me from ever looking at the MAP.  But then it's pretty hard to get lost on the Lexington Avenue #6 line -- even for someone like me with no sense of direction.

I'm sort of glad I didn't know any of those names, Malaika.  It made the puzzle far more challenging and far more fun for me than it would have been for the many younger people who probably did know them.  And I didn't even have to cheat.  Nice job.

Doubt if a paper route is a classic first job anymore.
It‚Äôs probably a disappearing job sad to say.

Creative baristas espresso themselves.

(Their ideas are brand-brew.)

Two things I noted: 

Fixating on the upcoming election, I felt that the answers APPRENTICE and STAY IN LINE were dog-whistling to potential voter/solvers ‚Ä¶

And separately, there are some anagram-adjacent connections between the constructor‚Äôs name (Malaika Hana) and HANA Mandlikova which just struck me as fun.

A nice Friday!

Just brewing a pot of lapsang souchong after finishing. 1a is nice with it but you can't really dunk it like you can a ginger nut. 

12d in a crowded polling place? Tsk! Last week I voted in my 14th general election and I've never been in and out in more than five minutes!

My nephew is doing a co-op program in Germany this summer, and is taking every opportunity to travel on the weekends. Doing the Grand Tour, if you will. Anyway, he is using my sister's credit card, because she has a rewards plan for international travel. So, she gets alerts for his expenditures of EUROS. Hmm, he rented an E-bike in Stuttgart at 2 AM? The most amusing notification was that he got Starbucks...in Paris. What? No picturesque cafe on the Champs Elysees? (His girlfriend was visiting at the time.) Kids today. In two weeks, he will be at the Belgian Grand Prix at SPA. I'm so jealous!

A tad baffled that "digital art" is the answer for "what DALL-E creates". That might have been a neutral take when it had its boom of popularity in 2021/2022, but we knew then and we certainly know now that what these machine learning models output are amalgams of thousands and thousands of artists' works, used as training data without permission. Many of my friends are digital artists and make their livelihoods that way. The constructor notes some other neat digital artworks in her notes. DALL-E and other text-to-image models are interesting and novel tools. But they are not artists.

Very thankful for the note about the Dall-E clue, because going through the puzzle I was MAD. Left the last three letters blank as long as possible. The fact is that software doesn't create anything. It is a tool, used by himans to create things. And in this case, by copying other things created even more directly by humans. Calling out a specific company just made it feel worse, like product placement in a crossword. 

Here are some ideas for a different clue, not perfect but at least accurate: 
Electronic music
Special effects
Rings, to a jeweler 
Fake nails
Binary beauty
7 segment displays

oh that was nice and crunchy ~ not too tough, not too easy

happy friday, everyone!

Very super cute! The top left corner had me tied up for a bit but once I figured out the wordplay ‚Äúforever homes‚Äù I was good to go. There were a few answers, like GIRL that I plugged in laughing thinking it couldn‚Äôt be right and then cracked up again when it was.

Completed in just under 20 minutes, that's the fastest I've done a Friday puzzle! Super fun and a personal redemption for me given I struggled quite a bit on Wednesday's and Thursday's earlier this week.
Loved this one. Lots of smiles. Was stuck at the top left and 15A for the longest time, even though 15A was in fact my first job too!
The puzzle was fine, but I bristle at the idea that anything Dall-E or any of these other scraper/regurgitators create is "art" of any sort.

I love crosswords because some people find one puzzle too easy for a given day and others find the same too hard. Shows we all have different knowledge, experiences, and fun facts lodged away in our brains. For me, this was a fast thrill! A luck of the draw with many clues catered to my knowledge base. Next week, I‚Äôll likely return to my 30-45 minute Fridays with one or two look-ups. But today I‚Äôm relishing in my new personal Friday record‚Äî15 minutes!! Without any wikipedia usage (lol)!! 
üíÉüèºüíÉüèºüíÉüèº
What a challenge! Took me forever but eventually worked it out. The title of the column was the eureka moment. After that things slowly fell into place. Vexing but enjoyable!

This was a perfect Friday puzzle for me, great clueing that was challenging at times but not terribly frustrating. I did look up the actress, KAT Dennings, and I got some things with help from the crosses. I don‚Äôt think I would have seen GIRL for ‚ÄúLet me tell you . . .‚Äù on my own. Nor would I have know about the example for DIGITAL ART. Thanks, Malaika Handa, for the challenge and the fun. I will watch for your name on future puzzles. 
I wish everyone a good weekend. The severe weather, from hurricanes to extreme heat in many places, is pretty scary.

Nice puzzle Ms. Handa!  I loved the wordplay. The clues were fun and I enjoyed all the aha moments.  I did the west side of the puzzle with less angst than the east.  I had so many ways to solve that shrinking, crashing clue! Crosses ended the struggle. Lightbulbs went on rapidly on the SW corner as soon as I solved 67A. Guessed successfully AI clue and worked my way back up for a few more passes. Once I swapped out twang for drawl it was Katie bar the door!  Thank you Ms. Handa and NYT for a fun Friday morning.  Cheers from Texas!
The product of composting is not soil, it is organic matter, one of the components of soil (mineral matter, organic matter, air, and water). I know. I'm a nerd, a soil science nerd.

Off topic

Thanks to Barry Ancona and Vaer for responding to my query about puzzles the week of Oct. 12, 2015.  (There are no Wordplay columns back then.) I hadn't considered xwordinfo.com. Thanks Vaer.
you all are the most pretentious people on planet earth. thanks for making the NYT's crossword the best hate-read on the internet!
I stuck with TELLS for table reads for the longest time.  Leonardo told me otherwise.
This was such a fun puzzle! I have never felt so old as I revel in completing a crossword but I‚Äôve still got my joy, so‚Ä¶
There‚Äôs a sense of pride when I get a Friday:)
My new friday best! Such a fun puzzle :D
Love the mini theme of rotting rinds - it was well composed - but ultimately this puzzle was too easily de-composed for me.

Was able to complete this without hints, which is very rare for a Friday for me! This one was really lovely to fill in; it all pieced together very nicely for me. Particularly loved DIAL, CRAZYSTRAW and EUROS. Thanks, Malaika!
First Friday completion!
This was fun for a Friday! I had CRAZY Mural for CRAZY STRAW and didn‚Äôt know what DEt was in the morning but @Deb pointed out DEW.  Thanks, Malaika! Good one.

This was so much fun! I know it's going to be a good day when Taylor Swift makes an appearance.

I had to reveal one letter, the "T" connecting ROTS and CRAZYSTRAW, but that was it. Pretty darn good for me for a Friday puzzle!

I suppose there is always a tension in crossword puzzles between trivia quiz and word game, but the best are always weighted heavily toward the latter, for they force you to struggle with the meaning of words, not simply know the things to which they refer.  This one is certainly far from one of the best.
@Steve L That would be a grid killer, 10 letters, half of them hard to with with. Though if PAOLINI wins on Saturday, she'll be a lot more crossword friendly

@Hillary Rettig 

That's what I had too late last night, knowing that was probably the one keeping me from the happy music. (What do I know about ALT social media, now that I barely check my one and only anymore -- (FB) ?? )

(And that most of what I know about current slang and social media shortcuts, I've learned from Xwords -- and so ANT seemed just as plausible -- b/c, well, every generation likes to tweak current usage to their own secret code -- Woah.)

Good night's sleep and MALONE seemed as good as guess as anything else, so replaced it, fingers crossed!

Phew ...
@Hillary Rettig I love that.
@Elyse My fastest Friday, too! But took me 12 minutes.
@Elyse Same! Well, fastest for me...just over 10 minutes.
@Aaron this one was slower than my average, however, there was a good vibe.

@Aaron 

Very much agreed.  This didn't seem like a Friday, and I don't think I've gotten much smarter lately...

@Aaron 
I feel like they were even easier a couple months ago. Seems to me like they might be getting a little better at dialing in the right level of difficulty

@Andrew

Oh thanks for sharing your streak! Impressive! I‚Äôm at 1725, and back at 1,000 I had to email them because a software glitch interrupted mine and I was despondent. I know a lot of folks think it‚Äôs a silly thing to care about, but I asked my husband to include it in my epitaph (only half joking).

@Andrew - Congrats!  I just got 2 yrs myself this week.  Not sure where to go from here.  1000 is obviously the next milestone, but at this stage, I think it's safe to say "I do the NYTs Crossword everyday" whether I keep the streak alive or not.  Was that the goal?  No idea... but it's my reality.  I do feel pressure to keep it alive when we're on vacation or if I get stuck on a tricky Sunday or something.

The last streak breaker was the Sunday puzzle with ZAZZIEBEATZ (about 2 yrs ago, lol).

@Natalia
I love that here we can say ‚Äúon Friday‚Äù when it‚Äôs Thursday but we all know what that means. I‚Äôve been doing the puzzle every evening (as soon as it‚Äôs released) for more than four years but I still have to explain to my husband that it‚Äôs Friday in puzzle time even though it‚Äôs not Friday.
Nicely done, @Natalia!
@Natalia I was pretty proud that I had only one lookup--Mandlikova--so I can understand your thrill!

@john ezra NW stymied me.

I had "CARP" rather than "HARP" that finally drove me to peek.  But of course,  HARP is way better, my modest english held me back.

No "SCORT" start to anything that goes with tea.  Arggh.

Then ROTS for turns... never would have made that particular connection.  And I'm too old for CRAZYSTRAW, never saw one.

But I did get PAPERROUTE!  Finally something for an old guy, I had one.

@Brady Rhodes 

Same for me, I also had 'got' instead of TRY to keep up.

@UpATree 

Doesn't the product of composting contain air and water?  I mean, it must, right?   It must contain air in the same way soil contains air--little pockets between the solid particles?

And I'm pretty sure if you start with refuse like apples and carrots, which contains water, you'll end up with something that has water as well.  Composting doesn't produce dry matter.

It might even have some mineral matter as well, depending on the components that go into the compost.  Wiki tells me fruits and vegetable contain minerals.

I would imagine the percentage composition is different than the normal stuff you dig in your garden, but they seem qualitatively the same, if quantitatively different.

@UpATree - This is a first -- pedantry about pedology! 


It's a puzzle. Not a scientific treatise.

@Jess 

When I began solving in the dark ages, I scanned the clues for gimmes. 
Facts, names, lyrics‚Ä¶that I was certain of and used those scattered about to build on.

As the years go by, the challenge wanes, so like many, I changed my strategy to NW, left to right, ending in SE.

Early week, sometimes later, my goal is to never move the cursor, but fill in each letter in order. 
No jumping around.

For fun on early-week puzzles, sometimes I randomly pick a square with my eyes closed, and use that as the starting square.

Anyway, that‚Äôs my nerdy game!

A highly caffeinated puzzle, if you include the accompaniment to SHORTBREAD. My go-to recipe for shortbread replaces some of the wheat flour with rice flour--I hear a gasp up in Glasgow--which lowers the gluten content. Also, it's one of the few recipes for which I will splurge and buy expensive, European(-style) butter, with a low whey content and a healthy amount of butyric acid* Assuming semesters spent abroad are spent in the Eurozone is, well, rather eurocentric. Why not spend that half-year where they spend the sol? Speaking of which, here's an interesting little tidbit TIL on Wikipedia: "The sol replaced the Peruvian inti in 1991 and the name is a return to that of Peru's historic currency, as the previous incarnation of sol was in use from 1863 to 1985. Although sol in this usage is derived from the Latin solidus (lit.‚Äâ'solid'), the word also means "sun" in Spanish. There is thus a continuity with the old Peruvian inti, which was named after Inti, the Sun God of the Incas." Or as they say in Cuzco, Money inti everything. Here's a little ditty to enjoy with your tea and shortbread (Go, Bees!): https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KdHMcTYtM_k *Butyric acid is the organic compound which, in small quantities, makes butter taste like butter, and in large quantities, makes butter taste like rancid butter.

@Bill 
While we're on the topic of coffee (I'm on my fourth cup)--down in Andean South America, the standard form of coffee is a sort of americano. If one orders a coffee, for a couple of soles or Ecuadorean sucres, one might be presented with a cup of hot water (or milk) and a cruet of a dark, syrupy liquid called *tintura* or *esencia de caf√©*, which one mixes in to taste. In a good establishment, this will be sweetened, super-strong espresso; in poorer ones, it will be a concoction of sugar and instant coffee. Nescafe sales are big down there.
